title: For Sale:  H&K 94 9mm carbine, "yippee ki yay, mother f^@% â¬ r!"
postcontent:
The most elegant carbine design in my estimation, classic tactical happy time. There's no box, but has the two stock types, John McClane style carry sling, special clamping rail on top, and four 30 round magazines, 2 curved, 2 straight.
 I'm being really fair on this in my estimation, based on how few there seems to be to price compare to, and then going lower by a grand. (keep in mind, this is W. German marked all real import, not like a Vulcan built post '90) 
 I'll consider some partial trades, but prefer to not take more than 700 in a trade item/s. A ps90, H&K SL8 converted into a G36, M1A, AR10 variant, or Steyr Aug would be exceptions that I'd consider up to 1400. Trades I'd really like to see: an Extar exp 556 pistol, preferably just plain and used price of 475 or less, or a Kel Tech PLR-16 under msrp priced (665). Sure, an extra mag or two, or especially a single point sling would be cool ad ons, but not hundreds in optics and furniture, I am looking for cash, so can forego all the gun bling that seems trendy lately. Okay, maybe a Pap 85np, but I prefer the lighter weight guys. Other trades I would highly be interested in, Commander or Government sized 1911, FNX/FNP 45, Sig 220 or 227 or full sized 250 in .45, Berretta 92, or a Taurus 608 4 or 5" barrel (8 shot .357). The S&W version, 686 I believe, is great too if not premium priced. Offer something cool, it might be on my long wishlist.

title: For Sale:  Sig Sauer P238 SAS .380
postcontent:
I have a Sig Sauer P238 SAS for sale. The SAS Model is similar to the standard P238, but Sig put it through a radical dehorning process resulting in a ultra smooth, snag free profile that is designed for concealed carry. There are no corners on this gun because of this process, and it makes it very comfortable to hide or conceal.

It is very much like a conceal size version of the 1911. The overall length is 5.5" and the overall height is 3.96". The SAS weighs 15oz so it fits great as a pocket carry weapon. It has gorgeous wood grips and has the SigLite night sights on it.

I bought it for my wife, and she put 2 boxes of .380 shells through it, and decided it was too small for her liking. The SAS has the smoothest slide I have ever found on a new gun.

The SAS comes with the original lockable hard case. Also, an extra magazine with the pinky extension, a holster, the lock, and test fire shell.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

title: For Sale:  Remington Model 17 Pump Action 20ga Shotgun 1926 Production Date
location: Spring Lake Park, Minneapolis / St. Paul, Minnesota
postcontent:
Remington model 17 pump action 20ga shotgun in good condition. All original shotgun with matching barrel and receiver numbers. Shotgun was made in 1926 according to the barrel code. Action is still smooth and locks up tight. This design was later used by Ithaca in thier model 37 pump guns. Bluing is very decent considering its age though it has lightened in the usual handling areas. 28" barrel has a clean mirrorlike bore with a fixed full choke. This would make an excellent addition to your Remington collection as they were only made for a short time frame.Â More info on the Remington 17:In 1915 John Browning patented a pump-action shotgun with the following features: hammerless, under-loading, tubular-magazine, bottom-ejecting, and take-down. This design would eventually become the Remington Model 17.[1] Manufacturing rights were sold to Remington Arms shortly after, but due to the production efforts of World War I, Remington was unable to begin manufacturing until 1921. Before production began John Pedersen made alterations to the design, with more changes made later by G.H. Garrison. The Model 17 was a trim, 20-gauge shotgun that served as the design basis for three highly successful shotguns: the Remington Model 31, the Ithaca 37 and the Browning BPS. Additionally, features of the Model 17 were also incorporated in the later Mossberg 500 and Remington 870.
Â 
Description: Pump action, hammerless, underloading, tubular-magazine, bottom-ejecting, takedown shotgun

title: For Sale:  300 black out pistol (parts or the whole thing)
postcontent:
I have decided that I don't have time to reload 300 blackout and refuse to spend so much for the cost of 300 blk ammo right now, so I want to sell part or all of this gun so that I can build something in 5.56/.223.

I'm mainly interested in selling the Sig brace w/ buffer tube as a unit and the barrel, gas block, muzzle brake and hand guard as a unit and keeping my upper, lower, BCG, and sights and optics for my next build.  See descriptions and prices below.

CMMG 8" barrel, low profile gas block with tube, bird cage brake, quadrail guard $235
Gen 2 Sig Brace w/ Mid West Industries tube -- sold. Gun now has a PSA pistol tube in place of the Sig Brace
AFG--sold

Whole gun minus sights and optics--$600. 
Complete upper--$430
Upper minus BCG = $340

Parts list for the gun: Anderson lower with PSA pistol lower parts kit, SAA upper (was told by SAA it is made by Aero), Mil-Spec charging handle, Nickel Boron carrier (8620 steel) and a 9310 steel bolt from SAA (was told by SAA it is made by WilTec).  This gun has a couple of magazines through it and functioned perfectly.  

I'd also be interested in trading for some of the following items:  14.5 or 16" 5.56/.223 barrel w/ carbine length gas system, slim keymod hand guard (13-15"), magpul or DD vertical grip, or a whole gun that is set up with some or all of the parts mentioned above.  I would be interested in trading +/- cash either way, however I do expect your parts to be in equally good condition.  They don't have to be top shelf parts of the AR world, but they do need to be in good shape.
Thanks for looking.

title: For Sale/Trade:   guerrilla gun / slam fire 12 g  bet you haven't seen this taking offers
location: Traverse city, Northern Lower Peninsula, Michigan
postcontent:
These weapons were originally invented and used by Filipino guerillas during the American occupation of the Philippines and continued to be used during World War II and can still be found in use currently. The shotgun above consists of a crude barrel made from a soft metal tube sliding over another tube. The user would push it forward (as shown in the image above) and load a cartridge into the back of it. The firing mechanism was extremely primitive as well. It consisted of a fixed firing pin, which was a nail that was fixed to the handle. To fire it, the user would simply slide the barrel back hard enough so that it slammed against the nail, which would detonate the cartridge and fire it. There was no rifling in the barrel and the weapon was only effective at short ranges and was mainly used to disable an enemy and take his firearm. Several guerillas who had fought with Richardson used these weapons against the Japanese.

It's in good shape and fires!! I personally shot it , unique peice one of a kind for sure

I can get more detailed photos with reply

postcontent:
I have a new Kel-Tec PMR 30 for sale. It is black in color and comes with two 30 round magazines in the factory hard case.Â $500.00 out the door sales tax included. REDACTED

The PMR-30 is a light weight, full size pistol chambered for the flat-shooting .22Magnum cartridge (.22WMR). The PMR-30 operates on a unique hybrid blowback/locked-breech system. This operation system allows for the use of a wide variety of ammunition as it seamlessly adjusts between locked breech and blowback operation, depending on the pressure of the cartridge. It uses a double stack magazine of a new design that holds 30 rounds and fits completely in the grip of the pistol. The trigger is a crisp single action with an over-travel stop. The manual safety is a thumb activated ambidextrous safety lever (up for SAFE, down for FIRE). The slide locks back after the last shot and a manual slide lock lever is also provided. The light, crisp trigger pull and fiber optic sights make the PMR-30 ideal for target shooting and hunting small game.
Â 
Slide and barrel are 4140 steel, frame is 7075 aluminum. Grip, slide cover, trigger, mag release, and safety levers are glass reinforced Nylon (Zytel), much like other Kel-Tec Pistols. Magazine is Also Zytel and holds 30 rounds, with round count ports. Other features include: dual opposing extractors for reliability, heel magazine release to aid in magazine retention, dovetailed aluminum front sight, Picatinny accessory rail under the barrel, Urethane recoil buffer, captive coaxial recoil springs. PMR30 disassembles for cleaning by removal of a single pin.

title: For Sale/Trade:  1912-61 Steyr in 7.62x51...5shot bolt-action...
postcontent:
This is a 1912-61 Steyr Waffenfabrik from Austria. Originally manufactured for the Chilean government this rifle was arsenal converted by NATO in 1961 and then warehoused. Unlike many conversions done on earlier model Mauser actions these were done by removing the old barrel (which was originally in 7x57 Mauser) and then cutting the chamber back. New , unissued Springfield 1903-A3(some 2 groove and some 4 groove) barrels were then fitted to these new chambers . This is NOT a barrel sleeve/solder fill conversion.
 Bore on this rifle is immaculate....This rifle still has the full military stock with bayonet lug and cleaning rod....The headspace has been checked by qualified gunsmiths... While it is not numbers matching this one comes with a hard to find factory turned down bolt.... 23" barrel... Receiver and stock have matching numbers... Overall good to very good condition..... looking to see what kind of offers I can get... I really like pre 1900 offbrand pistols....would trade  for a decent SKS.... I also have 1924 Deutschewerke semiauto pistol in 32acp in another ad...check it out... willing to trade both in the right deal....

title: For Sale/Trade:  1924 Deutschewerke semiautomatic  in .32 acp
postcontent:
This is a 1924 6th  and final model variant of the Ortgies pistol. Deutschewerke bought the company in 1921...ceased production of this pistol in 1925.... 
This has an original factory shiny nickel finish...and case hardened trigger...not very common at all...
all numbers matching pistol in roughly +85% condition. There is use and holster wear on the finish. Bore on the barrel is very good.
 These pistols were one of the most used in Germany during the time period... Over 70% of Target Pistol winners in 1921 were using this pistol in this caliber.
Has one original magazine which holds 8 rounds...prices on these originals are $100-130 each....
New firing pin/spring/plunger.
 Backstrap forward pressure safety release.
 All hand tooled forged steel....
 A beautiful example of how firearms used to be manufactured...plus a great  shooter...
Prices on the pistol go from 300-600 depending on rarity....and this is the only variant model to have the shiny nickel finish and color case hardened trigger from the factory.... 
must have CPL  or pistol purchase permit...$400 cash or trades considered listed below...

title: For Sale:  Politically Incorrect Colt 1911 Confederate Collector 45. --Price Reduced--
postcontent:
COLT Collectorâs Commemorative Confederate Air Force MARK IV SERIES 70 1911

Rosewood grips with gold Colt medallions, left and right.

Confederate Air Force Commemorative MARK IV SERIES 70

Engraved on this 1911 Series 70 Mark IV handgun is an image of a Confederate Colonel in Uniform all in Gold. 

This is Number 94 of 150 ever made, there will never be any others made.

This gun Has never been fired.

The second photo show white where it is really the same gold - that is just a bad reflection in the photo.  The gold engraving is consistent.

Carefully made and fitted in Coltâs Custom Shop.
The blued finish is rich and deep. 
Stunning Gold Engraving
Incredibly smooth trigger pull.
The MARK IV SERIES 70 was one of the most accurate Colt 1911âs ever made.
This is Number 94 of 150 ever made, or will ever be made.

These guns have the âclassicâ look and are cherished by their owners.

Caliber: .45 ACP 
Action: Recoil-operated single-action semi auto 
Frame: Carbon steel 
Slide: Carbon Steel 
Barrel: 5 inches 
Rifling: 6 grooves, LH, 1:16 
Magazine: 7 rounds 
Sights: Drift-adjustable rear, ramp front 
Trigger Pull: 4 lbs., 9 ounces (average) 
Overall Length: 8.5 inches 
Width: 1.25 inches 
Height: 5.75 inches 
Weight: 39 ounces 

$1,375.

The original name, Confederate Air Force, started as a simple tongue in cheek joke, poking fun at the organization's ragtag beginnings. As the collection of Warbirds at Central Valley Airport in Mercedes, Texas started to grow, someone painted the name on the side of the original North American P-51 Mustang Red Nose. The name stuck, and it grew to the point where the airport was renamed Rebel Field, all members were called "Colonels" (a tradition which still remains), and it led to the creation of a fictitious leader named Colonel Jethro E. Culpepper. There was even a humorous CAF twist put to the old AVG Flying Tigers World War II "blood chit" that read, "This foreign person has come to China to help in the war effort. Soldiers and civilians, one and all, should rescue, protect, and provide him medical care." The CAF version seen on the backs of flight suits and flight jackets stated, "This is a CAF aviator. If found lost or unconscious, please hide him from Yankees, revive with mint julep and assist him in returning to friendly territory. CONFEDERATE AIR FORCE".

In 2002 it changed its name to Commemorative Air Force after a vote of the membership. Many felt the name Confederate Air Force was confusing, was not politically correct, did not accurately reflect the purpose of the organization, and was detrimental to fundraising efforts. This name change was deemed by some fans to be a move of political correctness. The reason for the name change as stated by the organization was "Because the word 'Confederate' is offensive to some.

The origin of the CONFEDERATE AIR FORCE" dates back to 1957, when Lloyd Nolen and four friends purchased a P-51 Mustang, each sharing in the $1,500 cost of the aircraft. With the purchase of the Mustang, known as Red Nose, the group was unofficially founded.

In 1958, the group made their second purchase of two Grumman F8F Bearcats for $805 each. Along with the P-51, this gave the pilots the two most advanced piston-engine fighters to see service with the U.S. Army Air Forces and the United States Navy.

In 1960, the CAF began seriously to search for other World War II aircraft. The CAF Colonels were shocked to find that the aircraft which played such a major role in winning World War II were being rapidly and systematically scrapped as obsolete. No one, not even the Air Force or Navy, was attempting to preserve one of each type of these historic aircraft for display for future generations. The warbirds that remained airworthy were mostly in private hands modified for air racing or had been converted for commercial use as air freighters and aerial firefighters.

On September 6, 1961, the âCONFEDERATE AIR FORCE" was chartered as a nonprofit Texas corporation to restore and preserve World War II-era combat aircraft. By the end of the year, there were nine aircraft in the CAF fleet. Their first airshow was held on March 10, 1963.

In 1965, the first museum building was completed at old Rebel Field, Mercedes, Texas. The CAF created a new Rebel Field at Harlingen, Texas, when they moved there in 1968, occupying three large buildings including 26,000 square feet (2,400 m2) of museum space. The CAF fleet continued to grow. By the end of the decade, the CAF fleet included medium and heavy bombers such as the North American B-25 Mitchell, B-17, Consolidated B-24 Liberator. In 1971, they added the world's only airworthy Boeing B-29 Superfortress, FiFi.

The group's accomplishments were recognized in 1989 when it became a National Aviation Hall of Fame Spirit of Flight Award winner.[2] 1991 marked the beginning of a new era for the CAF with the opening of the new Midland, Texas, headquarters and museum facilities. Once in Midland, the group also established the American Airpower Heritage Museum and the American Combat Airman Hall of Fame.[3][4]

In April of 2014, the CAF announced the move of their headquarters and all of the planes associated with the headquarters to Dallas Executive Airport in Dallas, TX The museum and its artifacts (including the nose art collection) will also be moved to the new headquarters in Dallas. 

You may never have another chance to own a Colt 1911 as beautiful, unique and politically incorrect as this treasure. 

The only reason I am selling it is that I am 73 years old and have serious medical problems and have no family members who would appreciate what this is. So I want to sell this to someone who can appreciate it as much as I have.

The photos do not show the proper color of the gold. It is consistent in color and depth throughout. The lighting in the photo has distorted the color of the engraving and the bluing. This gun is incredibly beautiful and the photo does not do it justice.

The DB9 is an outstanding pocket-carry design with a smooth trigger, very similar to a Glock (even down to its take-down method).  It's light weight with an ultra-flat profile (11 oz. weight & 0.8 inch width) and that makes it the lightest, slimmest, and smallest 9mm available (you wonât have to settle for a .380).  It's easy to pocket carry and  just disappears in your pocket or purse.

Iâve found that the DB9 likes a steady diet of Remington UMC 115 gr JHPâs.  These rounds run toward the lower end of the SAAMI spec for overall length.  Iâve put a digital caliper on these rounds and they average about a thousandth of an inch shorter than most other 9mm roundsâ¦certainly within the SAAMI spec but just short enough to accommodate the tight tolerances of this micro-nine.  This DB9 loves them and if you feed it well, it will perform for you.

The full package comes with Diamondbackâs really nice hard case (like a Pelican case), trigger lock, all paperwork that came from the factory (as shown in photo) including the unused factory Warranty/Registration card.
